isis.stitle: TSI 92-08-05 - Calibration Procedure for Motorola 86MM Speedometer/Odometer and Tachometer

subjectgroup.subject: Calibration Procedure for Motorola 86MM Speedometer/Odometer and Tachometer

geninfo.para: This TSI describes calibration procedures on 1985-1989 S-Series vehicles.

This document contains three charts. Two of the charts ( Figure 5, Figure 6, Figure 7, Figure 8, Figure 9, Figure 10, and Figure 11) list the binary codes used to program (set) the DIP switches on the Motorola 86mm electronic speedometer/odometer instrument. The third chart ( Figure 12 and Figure 13) lists the binary codes used to program (set) the Dip switches on the Motorola 86mm electronic tachometer instrument. See " Tachometer Information" Section for instructions and charts to program the tachometer.
The two charts for the speedometer/odometer include the instructions and formulas for calculating the pulses per mile number. This number is used to locate the appropriate binary code in the charts.

note.para: The pulses/mile number is based on tire revolutions per mile. When tire revolutions are stated in revolutions per kilometers, the kilometers must first be converted into miles (kilometers x 0.6214 = miles).

geninfo.para: Switch settings for most combinations of tire size (tire revolutions per mile) and rear axle ratio used with medium-to-heavy-duty trucks are listed.

The two charts for the speedometer/odometer are divided into three columns. The first column (Pulses/Mile) lists the number of pulses generated by the magnetic sensor for each mile the vehicle travels. The Pulses/Mile number is used to locate the appropriate binary code. The second column (Binary Code) lists the binary code associated with the Pulses/Mile number. The binary code is used to set the DIP switches.

The speedometer/odometer instrument is designed with two DIP switches. One is an 8-segment DIP switch used to program the speedometer function, and the other is a 10-segment DIP switch used to program the odometer function. However, since both speedometer and odometer functions are activated by electrical pulses generated by the same sensor, the same Pulses/Mile number must be used to determine the DIP switch setting for both functions.

The third column (Freq) lists a number representing the frequency of a test signal that can be used to check the DIP switch settings. See " Checking Speedometer and Odometer DIP Switch Settings" section for details.

svcproc.title: USING PULSES PER MILE TO PROGRAM THE SPEEDOMETER/ODOMETER
svcproc.para: Determine the type of sensor system (A, B or C listed below) with which the Motorola 86mm electronic speedometer/odometer is going to be used. Next, use the formula shown to calculate the pulses/mile number. Then locate the pulses/mile number in the first column of the respective chart. Note the binary code in the second column and set the DIP switches to match that binary code.

note.para: Formulas for A and B sensor systems use the number of tire revolutions per mile in the calculations. If this tire rating is not known, refer to " Determining Tire Revolutions Per Mile" section for instructions for determining tire revolutions per mile.

para.title: A. TRANSMISSION MOUNTED MAGNETIC SENSOR WITH SIGNAL GEAR

verbatim.line: Tire Rev's/Mile x Axle Ratio x Sensor Gear Teeth = Pulses/Mile

svcproc.para: Locate 28061 in the Pulses/Mile column of the respective chart ( Figure 5 in this case for the speedometer and Figure 7 for the odometer) and note the binary code listed in the second column. (8-digit binary code 01001110 for the speedometer function, and 10-digit binary code 0010101111 for the odometer function.)
Use these two binary codes to set the DIP switches as instructed in " Setting DIP Switches to Binary Code" section.

para.title: B. DRIVE WHEEL MOUNTED DISC AND MAGNETIC SENSOR

svcproc.para: FORMULA:

verbatim.line: Tire Rev's/Mile x Disc Slots = Pulses/Mile
Example: Assume 474 tire revolutions per mile and 120 slots in the sensor disc. Then,

svcproc.para: Locate 56,880 in the Pulses/Mile column of the respective chart ( Figure 6 in this case for the speedometer and Figure 9 for the odometer) and note the binary code listed in the second column. (8-digit binary code 01011101 for the speedometer function, and 10-digit binary code 0101100011 for the odometer function.)
Use these two binary codes to set the DIP switches as instructed in " Setting DIP Switches to Binary Code" section.

para.title: C. SIGNAL GENERATOR MOUNTED AT PENCIL GEAR

svcproc.para: FORMULA:

verbatim.line: Pencil Gear Rev's/Mile* x Signal Generator pulses per revolution = Pulses/Mile
*Use a "MILE-O-METER™ or equivalent to determine pencil gear revolutions per mile.
Example: Assume 1000 pencil gear revolutions per mile, and 30 pulses each revolution of the signal generator. Then,

svcproc.para: Locate 30,000 in the Pulses/Mile column of the respective chart ( Figure 6 in this case for the speedometer and Figure 7 for the odometer) and note the binary code listed in the second column. (8-digit binary code 00111110 for the speedometer, and 10-digit binary code 0010111011 for the odometer.) Use these two binary codes to set the DIP switches as instructed in the " Setting DIP Switches to Binary Code" section.

svcproc.title: USING PULSE COUNTER TO PROGRAM SPEEDOMETER/ODOMETER
svcproc.para: Connect a pulse counter (Motorola Model 7TE2001) to the speedometer magnetic sensor. Measure a distance of 1/10 mile (528 feet). Drive vehicle through the measured distance and record the number of pulses. Multiply the number of pulses recorded by 10 to obtain the pulses/mile number.

Locate this number in the Pulses/Mile column of the respective speedometer and odometer charts. Note the binary code listed in the second column. Use these two binary codes to set the DIP switches as instructed in " Setting DIP Switches to Binary Code" section.

svcproc.title: CHECKING SPEEDOMETER AND ODOMETER DIP SWITCH SETTINGS

svcprocinfo.para: The third column of the speedometer and odometer charts lists a test signal frequency for each binary code listed. This test signal can be applied to the speedometer/odometer instrument to check whether the DIP switches have been properly set to the binary code.

svcsubproc.title: SPEEDOMETER CHECK
svcsubproc.para: When the applicable test signal is applied to the instrument and the 8-segment DIP switch properly programmed, the speedometer pointer will indicate a speed of 60 MPH (96Km/H).

For example, a 466 Hertz signal is listed for the 8-digit binary code 01001110. When the 466 Hertz test signal is applied to the instrument and the 8-segment DIP switch is properly set to 01001110, the speedometer pointer will deflect to the 60 MPH (96 Km/H) numeral on the dial.

svcsubproc.title: ODOMETER CHECK
svcsubproc.para: When the applicable test signal is applied to the instrument and the 10-segment DIP switch properly programmed, the odometer will advance one mile for each minute the test signal is applied.

For example, a 469 Hertz test signal is listed for the 10-digit binary code 0010110000. When the 469 Hertz test signal is applied to the instrument for one minute and the 10-segment DIP switch properly set to 0010110000, the odometer will advance one mile.

note.para: For greater accuracy in the odometer test, a test period of five minutes using a stop watch is recommended. (A five-minute test will advance the odometer five miles.)

svcproc.title: DETERMINING TIRE REVOLUTIONS PER MILE
svcproc.para: When the manufacturer's tire rating is not known, the number of tire revolutions per mile can be determined by the following method:
A. DETERMINE TIRE CIRCUMFERENCE IN INCHES

step1.para: Position edge of carpenter's level on vertical centerline of driven tire on vehicle. See Figure 1. Place a mark near top of tire and a second one near the bottom of the tire.
With the carpenter's level still in position, mark a starting point on the floor aligned with the marks on the tire.
Move vehicle so that tire makes one complete turn (360°).
Position carpenter's level along marks on tire and mark the stopping point on floor in line with marks on tire.
Measure the distance between the two points in inches (accurate to within 1/10 inch). This distance is equivalent to the circumference.

svcproc.title: SETTING DIP SWITCHES TO BINARY CODE

step1.para: Remove snap-on cover(s) from DIP switch openings located at rear of housing.
Using a pointed tool ( Figure 2), set DIP switches to the appropriate binary code.

caution.para: To insure correct programming, hold housing so that the arrow above the word "TOP" points up and set switches from left to right.

svcproc.title: TACHOMETER INFORMATION
svcproc.para: The information in this section covers the 0-3000 RPM Motorola 86mm programmable tachometers. The tachometer processes signals generated by the teeth on a rotating flywheel. The number of teeth on the flywheel determines the binary code used to program (calibrate) the tachometer. The chart ( Figure 12 and Figure 13) lists the more commonly used flywheels in terms of the number of teeth the flywheels have.

The chart is divided into three columns. The first column lists numbers which represent the number of teeth on the flywheel. The second column lists the corresponding 8-digit binary code used to set the DIP switch to program the tachometer.
The third column lists a number representing the frequency of a test signal that can be used to check the DIP switch settings.

First determine the number of teeth on the flywheel. Locate this number in the first column of the tachometer chart and note the binary code in the second column. Set the DIP switch to match this binary code. See " Setting DIP Switches to Binary Code" section for instructions.

The third column of the chart lists a test signal frequency for each binary code listed. This test signal can be applied to the tachometer to check whether the DIP switch has been properly set to the binary code.

For example, a 1716 Hertz test signal is listed for the binary code 01010010 (103 teeth on the flywheel). When the 1716 Hertz test signal is applied to a tachometer properly programmed for 01010010, the tachometer pointer will deflect to the 1000 RPM mark on the dial.

note.para: Doubling and tripling the test signal will deflect the tachometer pointer to 2000 and 3000 RPM respectively.
